characters: AT HER DESK, MORE HALLWAYS... ENDING ON
DALLES 6, SALMON CREEK 8, DEPOE BAY 11, CAPE LOOKOUT 22,
TODAY IS MONDAY SEPTEMBER 30, 1963. THE NEXT MEAL IS LUNC
DEPOE BAY, SEAMANIS SERVICE, SPORT FISHING, BOATS FOR CHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we SEE is an ELEVATED SHOT of the distant mountains, rolling landscape and McMURPHY -- one cheek laid-open and crusted over with dried blood, his face and prison work clothes caked with dried sweat and dust -- as he sits on very top of a water tower watching the last rays of sunli A long moment passes before McMurphy's attention is drawn elsewhere and he looks down. REVERSE SHOT - McMURPHY'S POV Far below, in the prison yard a MAN is SEEN hurrying acrc the yard where he joins a group of men composed of armed prison guards, officials, and medics -- a stretcher, an ambulance, a fire truck and safety nets spread out at the base of the water tower. The man is seen talking to the officials, then a bullhorn is handed to him and they all up at McMurphy. McMURPHY As he looks down at them, a searchlight is turned on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through bullhorn) McMurphy! This is Doctor Shankle, from the infirmary. Can you hear me? McMurphy doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through bullhorn) Can you hear me, McMurphy? McMurphy doesn't respond. Another searchlight goes on as SECOND VOICE is PICKED UP on the BULLHORN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through bullhorn) Why don't we blast 'im, for Christ sake, he ain't gonna come down... you... The BULLHORN is TURNED OFF. A long moment passes as McMur continues to squat on the tower and wait. He shivers agai the coming night when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through bullhorn) McMurphy! I have the warden's promise. If you come down, nobody will hurt you! You'll be in my custody! I promise! An imperceptible smile appears on McMurphy's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange HUMMING SOUNDS, CLANKING PIPES and HISSING RADIAT as we see beds, with patients lying asleep, line two wall The third wall is a heavy gauge steel grill, with a door opens on to the day room. The door is open. On the far si of the day room, a long hallway with other doors opening rooms: the latrine, washroom, tub room, mess hall, seclus room, psychiatrist's office, visitors' room, etc. Across the day room, a glass enclosed nurses' station whe TURKLE, a Negro night attendant, is seen preparing to go duty. The CAMERA PANS the beds in the men's dorm. One man turns another twists, a third lies as if dead. CAMERA PAN ENDS on BROMDEN, who lies still, eyes wide ope very alert. He reaches down, plucks a stale piece of gum under the bed frame, puts it in his mouth and starts chew A beat, then Bromden carefully undoes the leather strap w binds him to the bed. He slips out of bed and quietly mak his way down the aisle, paying no attention to the other patients, some of who are beginning to stir awake. Ahead, at the end of the hallway, the door opens and thre Negro day attendants, WASHINGTON, WARREN and MILLER, dres in white uniforms, enter and move down the hallway and disappear into a side room. Bromden continues his silent journey towards the day room Turkle emerges from the side door to the nurses' lounge, up the hallway as MISS PILBOW, the day nurse, comes in, passing Turkle on the way out. She crosses to the nurses' station and enters as Bromden reaches the day room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Bromden makes his way across the day room, past the nurses' station, unnoticed by Miss Pilbow who is busy preparing the day's medication. Bromden is sliding along the hallway wall, when he is suddenly cut off by a mop which THUDS against one side of neck. A second mop yokes him on the other side. Bromden freezes. Terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin', Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goin' t'see the Big White Fathuh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goin' t'see the Big White Muthuh... They cackle, legs jiving, as the ammonia stings Bromden's eyes and burns his nose. He tries to twist his head, but Washington jams the mop harder. Bromden freezes, panic spreading across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haw, look at 'im, big 'nough to eat apples off my head an' he mine me like a baby... A KEY is HEARD hitting the lock in the main door. Washing very adroitly releases Bromden, hands him the mop, and tu along with Warren and Miller, to their duties, as BIG NUR enters the ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneously, as Big Nurse passes) Mornin', Miss Ratched...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, boys. She sweeps by and disappears into the nurses' station. Th three attendants put their mops and rags aside and start towards the men's dorm, leaving Bromden pressed against t wall, mop in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Big Nurse enters to be greeted by Miss Pilbow, who wea an enormous cross between her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Miss Ratched. It's a beautiful day, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mean old Monday, Miss Pilbow, mean old Monday... (she flips on the intercom) Good morning, boys. Rise and shine. Rise and shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Washington, Warren and Miller roust the patients out o bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through loudspeaker) Time to get up! Come on now, it's a beautiful day! Let's not straggle! Everybody up, up, up! The Chronics are physically helped out of bed as the Acut who can handle themselves, cross out into the Day Room, rubbing the sleep out of their eyes. Big Nurse steps out the Nurses' Station. Washington and Warren are hustling t patients toward the washroom. Miller stays behind, stripping Blastic's bed and rolling his mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Acutes straggle past Big Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mister Sefelt... Good morning, Mister Fredrickson. Good morning, Billy, I spoke to your mother last night and she sends her love... Good morning, Mister Harding... Good morning, Mister Cheswick. Mister Scanlon... Bromden comes drifting by, going in the opposite directio Big Nurse takes his hand and reaches up and pats his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Mister Bromden... (calling out) Mister Washington! Washington comes running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Ratched?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Washington, why don't we get a good head start on the day by shaving Mister Bromden and see if we can't avoid a disturbance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Bromden by the hand) Yes, Miss Ratched...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients are busy washing and shaving. Warren is assisting a vegetable wash himself as Washingto guides Bromden through a cage-like partition... where an antique barber chair stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling as he goes) Warren! He sits Bromden down and straps his bands and legs in, th plugs the electric shaver in and turns it on and brings t BUZZING instrument towards Bromden's face. Bromden turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting out) Get your black ass in here! Warren props the vegetable up against the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tha's it... be right back! Warren leaves; the old man starts sliding.

dialogues.speaker: BROMDEN
dialogues.text: as Warren enters and takes a firm grip on Bromden's head Washington goes to work on Bromden's face. CAMERA PUSHES EXTREME CLOSEUP of Bromden's fearfully distorted face as BUZZING SOUND of the electric razor INTENSIFIES until it INSUPPORTABLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No sound as we SEE Big Nurse watch the last few patients past the side door to the Nurses' Station where Miss Pilb hands out little cups with pills. Washington stands by, checking to see each man takes his pills before filling t cups with orange juice. The last patient takes his pills and returns to his place the Day Room. Miss Pilbow closes the window. Satisfied that all is well, Big Nurse turns on an old 45 record player with a stack of records, then she settles d to her work as a SOFT, NOSTALGIC NUMBER from the '40's is HEARD OVER LOUDSPEAKER. CAMERA BEGINS SLOW PAN of the Day Room. The patients, under the influence of drugs, have settled for the day. HARDING is playing cards with MARTINI, CHESW and BILLY. SEFELT and FREDRICKSON are putting a jigsaw pu together in brotherly love. SORENSEN is off by himself, rubbing his hands clean. TABER, pencil in hand, sits pondering over a blank piece of paper. SCANLON paces back forth. On the Chronics' side of the room, RUCKLY is turni grimy photograph over in his hands. BANCINI sits wagging head, mumbling over and over, "Tired, awful tired..." ELL stands against the wall, arms outstretched, hands nailed the wall by imaginary nails. Bromden is pushing a mop around.  Washington, Warren and Miller are in the men's dorm makin the Chronics' beds when O.S. the TELEPHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Miss Pilbow picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty-two, Miss Pilbow speaking... Yes... (she makes a note and hangs it) ... New admission, Miss Ratched... Miss Pilbow goes to the mirror, quickly preens herself, t turns and flips the intercom on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over loudspeaker) Mister Washington! Mister Warren! She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Miss Pilbow exits nurses' station and heads down the hallway, Washington and Warren on her heels. Miller looki wistfully after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staff personnel are SEEN moving in and out of the main entrance where a state penitentiary car is parked. A DEPU SHERIFF leans on the fender smoking a cigarette as SECOND DEPUTY SHERIFF comes out of the building and motions down First Deputy, who crushes his cigarette out, then opens t rear door to the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to an unseen occupant) Okay, let's go. A long beat, then McMurphy slowly emerges from the car. H wearing handcuffs and dressed in faded jeans, flannel wor shirt, leather jacket, black motorcycle cap, and heavy bl boots. He's been scrubbed clean and has a Band-Aid on his cheek. McMurphy does a couple of knee bends to get the ki out of his legs as Deputy reaches in the car and takes ou small gym bag containing McMurphy's belongings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move it... McMurphy goes up the stairs, followed by the Deputy, and crosses into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as McMurphy enters the building followed by the Deputies, where Nurse Pilbow, McMurphy's folder in hand, and Washin and Warren stand waiting -- all in a pleasant, receptive mood. First Deputy hands McMurphy's gym bag to Washington who hands it to Warren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, this is it! McMurphy turns and holds out his hands. As cuffs are remo McMurphy impulsively takes hold of the Deputy's head and plants a kiss on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squirming out of McMurphy's grasp) Jesus, you're crazy, McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, ain't that the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Miss Pilbow) He's all yours, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Officer... The two Deputies start down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, fellas... The two Deputies merely shrug their backs at McMurphy who takes a deep breath of fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, it's a mighty nice fall day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am... McMurphy follows Nurse Pilbow into the hallway as the doo closes behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other STAFF MEMBERS are administrative personnel are SEEN McMurphy walks alongside Nurse Pilbow, who is noticeably nervous by his close proximity. Washington and Warren casually bringing up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he peels the Band-Aid off, revealing a scar) I tell ya, these goons showered me at the courthouse this morning, last night at the jail, and I swear they'd have swabbed my ears out on the way over if they could've found the facilities... A young Japanese nurse, named ITSU, passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nurse Itsu) Hey, how ya doin', cutie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just great! (calling after her) See ya around! Nurse Itsu laughs and disappears around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nurse Pilbow) Yes, sir, I sure am gonna enjoy my stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nurse Pilbow) Ya know, I ain't never been in an institution of psychology before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... They arrive at the ward door. Nurse Pilbow unlocks the do and opens it as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm here on a ninety-day observation period. Short-timer, like they say... Soft nostalgic MUSIC is HEARD OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. (indicating door) Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Nurse Pilbow enters the ward and McMurphy watches her cro the visitors' area to a heavy-gauge steel screen wall, wi security gate which she opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Washington and Warren as they step into ward) Man, there sure is an awful lot of poontang around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Hold it! McMurphy turns to see DOCTOR SPIVEY approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneously as Spivey passes into the ward) Mornin', Doctor Spivey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great day for fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneously) Yes, sir! The door closes. CAMERA HOLDS on sign that READS:  SMILE AT THE NEXT FACE YOU SEE. IT MAY SAVE HIS LIFE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was just thinking the same thing, Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as McMurphy, Spivey, Washington and Warren cross the visitors' area towards Nurse Pilbow, who stands holding t security gate open. At the far end of the hallway, which opens into the day room, patients can be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McMurphy) Oh, what's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, I'll betcha there must be a million albacore and tuna running of the coast right this minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, do you do much fishing? As they pass through the security gate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fish! Hell, Doc, I'd like to have a nickel for every fish I landed between Point Conception and the Alaska coast... Washington and Warren continue down the hallway, passing SEFELT, who shyly approaches and waits at a respectful distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McMurphy) Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup! Worked right outta Depoe Bay for just about every season since I was able to haul my own weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, my... Ah, who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McMurphy, Doc. R.P. McMurphy. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister McMurphy is a new admission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. Well, we must talk soon, Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet, Doc. Spivey turns to Sefelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Jim. How are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching and pointing to his mouth) Doc, my gungs hurt me. Spivey starts checking out Sefelt's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, Mister McMurphy. As McMurphy follows Nurse Pilbow down the hall, Spivey's voice trails after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been taking your Dilantin, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll send you over to the dentist and see what he can do. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Doc! McMurphy and Nurse Pilbow reach the day room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make yourself at home, Mister McMurphy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am, Nurse Pilbow enters the nurses' station, closing the door behind her. Next to the door is a bulletin board which, a other bits of information, READS:

dialogues.speaker: THE NEXT HOLIDAY IS HALLOWEEN.
dialogues.text: Another notice READS:  SIGN UP NOW! BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT STAFF VS PATIENTS. Washington, Warren, Miller There are no other names listed. Sefelt passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Sefelt crosses into the day room where he joins Fredricks who is putting a jigsaw puzzle together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as McMurphy drifts into the room and looks around. The ro is as it was. The MUSIC ENDS. There is a CLICK. McMurphy' attention is drawn to the nurses' station. McMURPHY'S POV OF NURSES' STATION where Miss Pilbow is SEEN through a large plate glass win busy typing a nameplate for McMurphy. Big Nurse, her back to McMurphy, is turning over a stack records. She presses the phonograph button. A record fall the turntable and MUSIC BEGINS as she turns and sees McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McMurphy smiles and tips his hat to Big Nurse.  Big Nurse smiles back and takes her seat.  McMurphy turns and drifts into the day room.  Big Nurse looks up and studies him.  McMurphy catches the eye of a PATIENT, sitting by himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin', buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poorly, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? What's ailing ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's too bad... Taber, pencil and paper in hand, crosses to McMurphy and him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, 'fraid not... Taber walks away. Martini tugs at McMurphy's sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you borrow me a dime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, buddy, I'm clean outta change... Scanlon moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too! Me too! As McMurphy hands out his cigarettes Bromden drifts by, m in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it look up there, big boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't hear you. He's just a deaf and dumb Indian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martini, it's your turn! Martini is staring off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Martini) Your buddy is callin' ya. Martini crosses back to the card game as Taber returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's troubling ya, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to write me a letter to my brother for a hundred dollars to bury me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look pretty healthy to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the next one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do ya know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I quit breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're breathin' right now. Taber walks away. McMurphy watches him go. Nearby, an OLD VEGETABLE squeaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing to him) What's that, Pop? The old man squeaks again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning in close) Can't hear ya, old-timer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't this a pisser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, compared to where I just come from, this is a country club. McMurphy crosses to the card game and stands watching the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha boys playin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H-H-Hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot! No wonder you don't care nothin' 'bout showin' your hand. Billy holds his hand close to his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-B-Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, put 'er there, Billy boy, my name's McMurphy. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I wanna know is who's the top loony around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-Y-You m-mean th-the pr-president of the P-P-Patients C-Council?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that'll do for openers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harding) H-H-Harding, the m-m-man w-wants to t-talk to you, y-you're the pr-pr pr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, do you have an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harding) What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a busy man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McMurphy) He's a busy man! A beat; then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can wait... McMurphy picks up a chair and sits down right next to Har and looks at him. Another beat; then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to McMurphy) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seeing what a busy man does. Harding, very nervous at McMurphy's proximity, turns back the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn, Martini! Martini is lost in the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martini, throw a card! Martini throws a diamond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, throw a club!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, throw a club! Martini throws a spade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you have any clubs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see your hand!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slamming his cards) Well, if you gentlemen will excuse me, I have some pressing matters to attend to. Harding gets up and crosses to the hallway, gathering his pride as he goes. McMurphy slides into Harding's seat and rakes all the car in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, that's why I came to this establishment for, to bring you birds fun and entertainment 'round the gamin' table... McMurphy fans the deck out and lays it on the table. Everyone's eyes pop as he scoops the cards up in one move -- he's a card shark, a magician -- leaving the Acutes wi their mouths hanging open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy now, don't smudge 'em, we got lots of games ahead of us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister McMurphy! McMurphy turns to see Big Nurse approaching, Washington casually bringing up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him his bag) Will you come with me, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Hold the fort down, will ya, fellas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mack! McMurphy walks with her toward the men's dorm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Miss Ratched. I'm the head nurse here. You've already met Miss Pilbow and Aides Washington and Warren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Big Nurse and McMurphy stop at the security gate to the m dorm where Miller opens the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Miller, this is Mister McMurphy, who'll be staying with us. Greetings are exchanged as they pass through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Big Nurse and McMurphy cross down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do appreciate the way you have taken it upon yourself to meet the other patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma'am... Big Nurse stops at an empty bed where Warren is turning t mattress down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your bed. You may leave your things in that cabinet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please use your time to familiarize yourself with your new home and if there is anything you need to know, don't hesitate to ask us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that you mention it, I sure would like to call my aunt up in Portland and tell 'er where I am so she can come visit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in good time, Mister McMurphy. All in good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Now if you'll just go along with Mister Washington, he'll see that you're properly oriented. McMurphy doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just that I'm glad to be here, Miss Ratched. I really am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'm sure we'll be friends. They smile, sizing up each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you ain't half so bad looking for a head nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Now go along, Mister McMurphy. Go along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. (to Washington) Lead the way, Sam. They cross out of the men's dorm. Big Nurse watches them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other work have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Spivey is seated behind his desk, on which are sev glass-framed photos of Spivey's family, plus a nameplate: JOHN M. SPIVEY, M.D., and McMurphy's papers. McMurphy, freshly showered and wearing hospital-issue clothes, sits facing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, Doc, I've been everything from a hoopla man with a two-bit carny show to a top mechanic and bull goose catskinner for every gypo loggin' operation in the Northwest till the Army taught me what my natural bent was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you know how society persecutes a dedicated man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say I'm a habitual hassler. Like I fight some. Sheeut. They didn't mind so much when I was a dumb logger and got into a hassle. That's a hardworkin' feller blowing off steam, they say. But if you're a gambler, all you have to do is spit slantwise and you're a goddamned criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To tell the truth, ever since I found my natural callin' I done time in so many small-time jails I could write a brochure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Ah, do you know why you're here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, ya know, Doc... (indicating his papers) Doesn't it say so there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over papers) Well, according to the Warden at Pendleton, you were a disturbing influence on others. 'It appears that there is a potential in him for instigating a revolt among the other inmates.' (looking up at McMurphy) What do you think of that report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't, Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goes back to papers) Arrested on an assault charge five times...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's correct, Doc ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from folder) The doctor at the prison states: 'Don't overlook the possibility that this man may be faking psychosis to escape the drudgery of the work farm...' What do you say to that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, what can I tell ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it seems you have no other psychiatric history, Mister Murphy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is my first trip, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closes folder and sits back) Well, you're here for a ninety-day observation period, Mister McMurphy. I'd like you to understand you are here on a court order and we are responsible to the state. So, I'd like your cooperation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet, Doc!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA is on Big Nurse as she stands, in front of a chair doing a deep breathing exercise. The patients and staff, standing in front of chairs arran in a circle, follow suit as best they can. After a couple exercises Big Nurse sits. The others do the same except Bancini, who remains standing, wagging his head back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired. Whew. O Lord. Oh, I'm awful tired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (busy with her papers) Somebody please see to Mister Bancini, so we can start the meeting. Billy does... gently laying a hand on Bancini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T-t-t-take it e-e-easy, P-P-P Pete...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful tired... Billy gently eases Bancini into his chair and sits beside him, patting his skinny knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the close of Friday's meeting, we were discussing Mister Harding's problem, concerning his wife... (reading from logbook) Mister Harding stated that his wife made him uneasy because she drew stares from men on the street. Is that correct, Mister Harding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's perfectly correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) He also thinks he may have given her reason to seek sexual attention elsewhere, but he didn't say how. He has been heard to say to his wife, 'I hate you, I don't ever want to see you again. You've betrayed me.' (she closes book) So. Does anyone care to touch upon this further? Big Nurse waits. A long beat. Harding sits, chewing his nails, tensely waiting, almost wanting someone to begin. The patients shift uncomfortably, looking in all directio McMurphy looks around to see what will follow, when he se Ellis, nailed to the wall; his pants leg darkens and a pu of piss forms at his feet. McMurphy looks to see if Big N or the Aides have noticed. If they have, no one pays any attention. McMurphy fidgets in his seat, then gets up, crosses to El unhooks him from the wall, and moves him over a few feet. The other patients are aghast at this move, look at each other quizzically. Big Nurse merely watches. McMurphy crosses back to his chair and sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister McMurphy, this ward is a democratic community run by the patients and their votes, so you should feel at ease in your new surroundings to the extent you can freely discuss emotional problems in front of the patients and staff. However, the cardinal rule, and I must emphasize this: Everyone keeps their seat during the meeting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, it just pains me somethin' awful to see a full growed man sloshing around in his own water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... We were discussing Mister Harding's problem with his wife. Now, who will start? (no response) Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-m-m-ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: N-n-n-n-n-no, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Sefelt? Sefelt shrugs and sinks into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Fredrickson? Fredrickson passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Taber? Taber passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Martini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Scanlon? Scanlon looks at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Cheswick? Cheswick wags his head 'no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I to take it that there isn't a man among you who has an opinion concerning this matter? (no response; she focuses in on Harding) Mister Harding, you've stated on more than one occasion that you suspected your wife of seeing other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Ratched, this is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you have no proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Miss Ratched...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yet you suspect her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only speculate as to the reasons why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever speculated, Mister Harding, that you are impatient with your wife because she does not meet your mental requirements? One of the Chronics laughs like a child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Ratched. Given all the conditions of that sublime relationship, coupled with the subsequent annihilation of all that I held to be sacred, mentally, physically and emotionally, the only thing that I can speculate on, at this late date, is how I will justify the very existence of my life, with or without my dear wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Harding, why don't you knockoff the bullshit and get to the point. Several Acutes chime in, "Yeah, get to the point," AD LIB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, I will carry on until I fully understand what the function of that relationship is regardless of form or content. Several hands go up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I-I-I-I d-d-don't s-s-see how anyone could lu-lu-lu-love a man who t-t-t-talks the way he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Harding, you're so fuckin' dumb I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a matter of opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Harding, where do you breathe anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the ass. Sefelt and Fredrickson snicker into their hands. A few of others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smarting) Is that your sense of humor or are you trying to say something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocence itself) Now what would I be trying to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know, but it makes me feel very peculiar when you throw in something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peculiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, tell us why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hesitate to go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No secrets, Mister Harding. Let's get it all out in the open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, the other day you made an allusion to my wife and the possible sexual problems we might be having. I know that to be the case, but the way in which you broached it, if that's your idea of teaching me something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his voice rising as he goes on) ... or making me aware of a condition in my life, then I say, categorically speaking, the hell with you, Taber! I don't have to justify the condition of my life to you or any of you. No matter what I will carry on until I fully understand what that function is regardless of the form or content. Regardless of the fact we must try to understand the function of our capacity to obtain, to personify the condition, the condition of our existence, our existence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Harding? I think you're some kind of morbid asshole or something. You've been talking about your wife evere since I can remember. You know, she's on your mind and blah, blah, blah and on and on and when are you going to wise up and turn her loose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, wise up, Harding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, turn her loose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (start pouring it on) Yeah, who do you think you are anyway?... He thinks he's God Almighty... He's a snob... He's a schmuck... Dumbbell... Creep... Cretin... Idiot... Get rid of him... Ship him upstairs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chiming in) Ffffffuck da wife...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wagging his head) Tired... Awful tired...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not letting up) Zap him... Give 'im lobotomy... Cut his nuts off... He doesn't have any... Fag... Pervert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a strong angry voice) I'm tired! Everyone hushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody see to Mister Bancini. Two or three Acutes get up and try to soothe Bancini, but isn't to be hushed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired. Tired. Oh God, I'm tired... Big Nurse nods to Washington, who goes to Pete, and gives arm a jerk toward the door. Bancini is unmovable. Big Nurse signals Nurse Pilbow, who heads for the nurses' station. Washington senses danger, lets go of Pete's arm, backs aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a good boy, Mistah Bancini... Nurse Pilbow returns, hypodermic needle in hand. Pete turns to his fellow inmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see... it's a lotta baloney... It's all a lotta baloney...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, Mister Bancini, now if you'll just be calm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all it is, just a lotta baloney. Ya see, I can't help it, can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working her way around Bancini) Yes, I know, I know... She gets him in the ass, with the needle, and springs bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... don't ya see. I was born dead. Not you. You wasn't born dead. Ahhh, it's been so hard... (starts going over, slowly; sighing and crying) Tired... I'm tired... aw-ful tired... McMurphy looks around at the others. Each patient is locked in his own world -- oblivious to Bancini's state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT of entire court, surrounded by a high fence top off with barbed wire, as Washington and Warren escort the Acutes -- including Bromden, Ellis, a lobotomy case and several other Chronics -- through the gate onto the court which is run down, with cracks in its surface and leaves scattered everywhere. Martini, who is carrying the ball, runs ahead, followed b Scanlon, where he starts dribbling the ball in a frantic circle, suddenly passes the ball to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he throws ball) Catch it! Catch it! The ball rolls to the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martini, there ain't nobody there, ya dumb goon! Go get the ball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Martini turns away, his feelings hurt. Washington goes af the ball, when Martini goes running after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get it! I get it! But Washington gives Martini a body check and beats him t the ball. Martini tries to get the ball from Washington, who is qui agile and teases him as he returns to the court where he Warren start shooting baskets, freezing Martini and Scanl out. The other patients just hang around or walk, as if in a prison yard. Cheswick stands in close proximity to McMurphy and Hardin who stand watching the action. McMurphy finally offers a cigarette to Harding, who accepts. They both light up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, say, buddy, is that the usual pro-cedure for those Group Ther'py shindigs? Bunch of chickens at a peckin' party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pecking party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, buddy. And you want to know who pecks the first peck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, come off it! It's that Big Nurse, that's who... The other Acutes have gathered around McMurphy and Hardin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's as simple as that. You've been on our ward six hours and have already simplified the work of Freud, Jung and Maxwell Jones in one grand analogy: it's a pecking party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking about Fred Yoong or Maxwell Jones, buddy, what I'm talkin' about is that crummy meeting and what that nurse did to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did to you and all the rest of you guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-y-yes! Yes! Y-y-y-you s-s-saw wh wh-what she c-c-can do to us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I see 'cept a grown man gettin' whipped so bad he can't laugh anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the questions she asks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'er to go straight to hell!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Ratched is a competent psychiatric nurse, not some, some kind of monster pecking out our eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as calm as blue waters) She ain't peckin' at your eyes, buddy. McMurphy grabs Harding by his balls and Harding goes up o his toes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's peckin' at your balls, buddy, at your ever-lovin' balls. Harding is doubled over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of behavior will get you a P.A. rating, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.A. What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potential assaultive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which gets you shipped up to Disturbed for a nice little zap job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electro-Shock Therapy, my friend. Five cents' worth of electricity and you are out of everybody's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'er to go to hell anyway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if you persist in your ways, they can always ship you over to Medical Surgery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobotomy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lobotomy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to lobotomy case) That! McMurphy looks.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF A LOBOTOMY CASE
dialogues.text: A vegetable, complete with two half-dollar scars in his forehead. McMURPHY As he absorbs this bit of information the basketball roll his feet and he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harding) Is that your sense of humor or are you tryin' to say somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what would I be trying to say? Martini and Scanlon rush over and try to get the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the ball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Me! Me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass the ball, McMurphy. McMurphy crosses to the court, bouncing the ball as he go When he reaches the court he holds the ball out to Washington, who reaches for it, but McMurphy snaps it bac over his shoulder to Martini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Martini) Pass it to me, Martini. Martini holds back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I'll give it back! Martini passes to McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta boy, Martini. He passes it back to Martini, who laughs and passes it ba to McMurphy, who passes it to Scanlon, who passes to McMurphy, who passes to Billy, etc. Bromden just stands watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (encouraging them) Back and forth, that's it. Shoot, man, we'll be takin' on the New York Knicks before we're through... McMurphy looks to see Big Nurse looking out a window at t He catches her eye. She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey-ya, hey-ya, come on, come on, I'm waitin' on you suckers, you hit or you sit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC is PLAYING. The TV is on the six o'clock news a McMurphy, cards in hand, is dealing blackjack to Cheswick Harding, Sefelt, Billy and Martini. Fredrickson and Scanl are looking on as Bromden eases up to the game. Cheswick at the nurses' station talking to Big Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit, you say? Well well well and with a king up, the boy wants a hit. Whadaya know. So comin' at you and too bad, a little lady for the lad and he's over the wall and down the road, up the hill and dropped his load.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boogered! McMurphy rakes in Sefelt's cigarettes, adding them to a p of loose cigarettes, packs of cigarettes, several cartons cigarettes. As Cheswick sits down, depressed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay, place your bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up a cigarette) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a dime, Martini. Martini breaks a cigarette in half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet a nickel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cheswick) Whadaya bet, Cheswick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't give me any more cigarettes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That okay. I'll take your marker. How many ya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lend me twenty. McMurphy counts out twenty cigarettes, marks it down on a piece of paper, and passes the cigarettes to Cheswick, wh bets all twenty. The Sports have come on TV and McMurphy's attention is divided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking the board) 'Kay, all bets are down, let's wheel 'em an' deal 'em. He deals the cards out, the first one face down, then the next one face up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big king... little deuce... another king... a lovely lady... big ten... and a trey... hey, hey, whadaya say? Ya hit or sit, Martini?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hits with a picture) That's twenty up, Martini. (turning to TV, he shouts across room) Hey, Taber, who's pitching the opening game? Taber calls back something but it's lost in the other sou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Martini, I can't hear a thing. (turning back to Taber) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting back) Koufax against Ford!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over loudspeaker) Medication time! Medication time! Medication!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simultaneously with Pilbow) Hit me! McMurphy slams his cards down, stands up, crosses the day room, heading for the nurses' station. He passes Washingt who stands there waiting to dispense orange juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as McMurphy enters. Nurse Pilbow is the only one there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me miss, but would you mind turning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared out of her wits) Stay back! Patients aren't allowed to enter the... Oh, stay back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I'm askin' is... Nurse Pilbow grabs at her cross, screams and shuts her ey holding the cross in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, stay back, I'm a Catholic! Big Nurse enters from the nurses' lounge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister McMurphy. Patients aren't allowed in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, ma'am. McMurphy steps out of the station, closing the door behin him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as McMurphy goes around to the front of the nurses' stati and queues up behind the other Acutes who are getting the medication. McMurphy reaches the window, takes the cup, b doesn't take his pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Big Nurse) Pardon me, ma'am, can I ask you somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) Yes, Mister McMurphy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout turning off that music for a while so a man can hear himself think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) That music is for everyone, Mister McMurphy. McMurphy leans in, placing his hand on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) Well, say, how 'bout easin' it down a bit so a man don't have to shout!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aware of his physical proximity) Mister McMurphy, there are old men here who couldn't hear the music at all if it were lower. That music is all they have, and I wish you wouldn't lean against the glass there, your hands are staining the window. McMurphy jerks his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, ma'am... Sorry 'bout that... McMurphy breathes on the glass and wipes it clean with hi sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to have bothered you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, Mister McMurphy... McMurphy turns to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your medicine, Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back, he examines the contents of the cup) What's the horse pill for, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just medication, Mister McMurphy, good for you. Now down it goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, miss, I don't like swallowing something without knowing what it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping back a little) Don't get upset, Mister McMurphy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not upset. All I wanna know, for the lovva Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Miss Pilbow, if Mister McMurphy does not wish to take his medication orally, he may...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's okay, ma'am. Down it goes. McMurphy makes a big show of popping the pill in his mout holding his paper cup upside down, for all to see, then moving on to Washington, who fills it with orange juice. McMurphy gulps it down, not without some difficulty, then smiles at all the concerned faces and crosses the room to card table, where he sits to see the Acutes looking at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell her to go to hell, lover boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, whattsa matter, Mack, she too much for ya? McMurphy holds the pill up and flicks it into Harding's forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys seem to think you've got a champ in there, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see you scoring any points, buddy. And you're just the man for the job, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I couldn't get it up over old hatchet-face if ya paid me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not all that homely, Mister McMurphy. In fact, she must have been a rather beautiful young lady. The men look at Big Nurse. The patients look at the nurses' station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Nurse is busy at her work.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The patients looking at her. They turn back to their card game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA HOLDS on Big Nurse as McMurphy's VOICE is HEARD ov INTERCOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through intercom) Yeah, an' I'm tellin' ya, she's just an icy-hearted over-the-hump gal who never got enough of the old wham-bam to straighten 'er out... Okay, who wants a card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through intercom) Me. Hit me! Big Nurse looks up and studies the men gathered round the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients are asleep except for Bromden, who stands by window looking out. McMurphy is asleep in the bed next to his. A beat when TURKLE, a fifty-year-old Negro night attendant, slightly drunk, lays a gentle hand on Bromden's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le's get back to bed, Mistah Bromden... Bromden allows himself to be led back to bed. Turkle fumb around for the security belt, finds it, straps Bromden loosely in bed, then goes off clucking to himself. Bromden reaches under his bed and plucks a stale piece of from under the bed frame. He starts chewing it when he se McMurphy looking at him. Bromden goes right on chewing and looking McMurphy right the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Chief? I wanna ask ya somethin'. (sings) Oh, does the spearmint lose its flavor on the bedpost overnight? When you chew it in the morning, will it be too hard to bite? This question's got me goin', won't somebody set me right; does the spearmint lose its flavor on the bedpost overnight? McMurphy holds the last note, reaches over and rustles through his nightstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here ya go, Chief... A small object lands on Bromden's bed. It is a fresh pack of gum. Bromden picks it up. Examines it. Unwraps it. Deposits his old piece of gum under the bed frame, then inserts the fresh gum in his mouth and starts chewing.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: SHOWING the MEN'S DORM, the empty DAY ROOM, TURKLE ASLEEP the NURSES' STATION, EMPTY HALLWAYS, the NIGHT SUPERINTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ABERRATED SHOT of INSTITUTIONAL GROUNDS SEEN THROUGH STEE MESH SCREEN -- as the sun rises above the treetops.

dialogues.speaker: BROMDEN
dialogues.text: looking out of the window. His face washed by the sunligh His eyes have a vague look, almost vacuous, as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through loudspeaker) Good morning, boys. Rise and shine. Rise and shine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Washington, Warren and Miller roust the patients out o bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through loudspeaker) Time to got up! Come on now, it's a beautiful day! Let's not straggle! Everybody up, up, up! McMurphy is in bed, not ready for the world, when Washing crosses to Bromden, who is looking out the window, and le him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le's go, Chief. Le's go get ourselves all nice and clean... (to McMurphy) You too, Mistah Mack-Murphy! Washington goes off with Bromden. CAMERA HOLDS on McMurphy as he slowly pulls it together a sits on the edge of the bed. He's naked as he opens the drawer to his nightstand and fishes around for a cigarett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking in the drawer) What the... (looking around) Who the fuck stole my cigarettes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the Acutes straggle past Big Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mister Sefelt, are your teeth any better?... Good morning, Mister Fredrickson... Good morning, Mister Harding; my, my, you've been biting your fingernails again... She sees McMurphy approaching, wearing a towel around his waist and a scowl on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister McMurphy, patients are not permitted to run around in towels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna report a robbery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On this ward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, some creep stole my cigarettes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I had them removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patients are rationed to one pack of cigarettes a day. Bromden comes drifting by, going in the opposite directio Big Nurse takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Mister Washington! Washington comes running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Ratched?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please see to Mister Bromden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Bromden by the hand) Yes, Miss Ratched... Washington leads Bromden off. Big Nurse turns to Cheswick several other Acutes, who have crowded around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you boys hurry along and wash up for breakfast... (to McMurphy) You too, Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, say. How 'bout springing a pack of cigarettes loose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After breakfast, Mister McMurphy, after breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure run a tight-assed ship 'round here, don't ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Now run along like a good boy and see that you wash up properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, as the Acutes wait for McMurphy's next move, then

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay, let's go brush our teeth, fellas... McMurphy turns and crosses toward the washroom, singing a the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Lulu had a baby, His name was Sunny Jim, She put 'im in a piss pot, To teach 'im how to swim. Oh, he swam to the bottom, He swam to the top, Lulu got excited, An' pulled 'im by his... Cock-tail ginger-ale, Five cents a glass, An' if ya don't like it Ya can shove it up your... Ask me no more questions, I'll tell ya no more lies.

dialogues.speaker: BIG NURSE
dialogues.text: watching McMurphy who removes his towel as he enters the washroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as McMurphy enters to see Warren take a firm grip on Bromaen's head and Washington goes to work on Bromden's f CAMERA PUSHES INTO EXTREME CLOSEUP of Bromden's fearfully distorted face as the BUZZING SOUND of the ELECTRIC RAZOR INTENSIFIES until it is INSUPPORTABLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We SEE the attendants spooning food into the sucking pink mouths of the vegetables, a shade too fast for swallowing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with you guys? We SEE McMurphy seated with the Acutes, shoveling food do his guillet. The others are barely touching their food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, if I'd have known how soft this place was gonna be, I'd have arranged for my transfer sooner... (holding up his orange juice) Look at this here, real orange juice! (slugging it down) Hooee, that's good. Why, you couldn't pay me to leave this place! (slaps his belly) All this place lacks is a couple of sweet gals to liven things up... He gets up and carries his tray to the proper place, wher notices Miller loading several other trays onto a dumbwai Miller pushes a button and the dumbwaiter goes down. McMu crosses to the door to find it blocked by Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand aside, Sam, Nature's callin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody leaves here till seven thirty. McMurphy turns Washington over in his mind, then he looks at the clock above the door. The time is 7:28. The second hand sweeping its way toward 7:29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know if I can hold it that long, Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tha's your problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) Who do you like in the opening game, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning away) Asshole. McMurphy turns and walks away. Washington watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna know about my cigarettes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group meeting is in progress. Doctor Spivey is there. Cheswick is on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Mister Cheswick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not sitting) No, I ain't no kid to have my cigarettes keep from me like cookies! Ain't that right, Mack! (McMurphy doesn't respond) Mack???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Mister Cheswick! Cheswick sits -- stunned. A beat; then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Cheswick) You should have thought about that before you gambled all your cigarettes away. Is that clear? Cheswick sulks in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Cheswick, is that clear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good... (opens her book) Now, as I recall, we were making quite a bit of headway, last time, with Mister Harding's problem. So, does anyone care to begin? McMurphy's hand goes up. No one else's does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right... I've been givin' some serious consideration to what you told me about the democratic something of this therapeutic community of ours, an' I got a few things I wanna get off my chest, before we get back to Harding's problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly, Mister McMurphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right! McMurphy takes a folded sheet of paper out of his pocket, unfolds it, studies it and begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Kay... Item one... I've been thinkin' 'bout the age problem we got on this ward. You know, the young an' old livin' together, an' I was thinkin' what a great thing it would be if the music was turned up louder. Louder so the old fellas could hear better... Doctor Spivey nods with approval. Big Nurse doesn't. The Acutes are bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then I got to thinkin', the music is so loud already, it makes it difficult for the young fellas to hold a decent conversation... Nods and murmurs of approval from the Acutes. Big Nurse can only wait for McMurphy's next move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was turnin' this dilemma over in my head, when I happened to hit on that old tub room out there, an' I said to myself, McMurphy, I said, that place would make a great second day room. A sort of game room for the young fellas. Whadaya think, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is worth considering... Miss Ratched?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is well taken, Doctor, but do we have the necessary personnel to cover a second day room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since it will be largely the Chronics who remain here, one aide and one nurse should easily be able to handle any situation that might occur. (he turns to the patients) What do you think, men, is it workable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Doc. It's workable. Several other Acutes voice in the affirmative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Good. Yes, yes, I think we should give it a trial period. So! May we get back to Mister Harding's problem... (she sees McMurphy's hand up) Yes, Mister McMurphy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not finished yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at his list) 'Kay, item two. Tomorrow, and listen carefully to me, you ding-a lings. Tomorrow is the opening game of the World Series an' what I want is to take a vote on switchin' the group meetin' to later on in the day, so we can watch the ballgame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a minute, Mister McMurphy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please understand, the schedule has been set up for a delicately balanced reason that would be thrown into turmoil by a switch of routines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell with the schedule, you can get back to the schedule next week when the series is over. What I want is a vote on it right now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I second the motion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Atta boy, Cheswick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well! All those in favor, please raise your hands. Big Nurse casts a watchful eye over the patients.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his hand) Okay, raise your hands. Only Cheswick's goes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on', what is this crap? Who wants to watch the World Series? Martini and Scanlon's hands go up. Several Acutes look at them. Scanlon and Martini's hands go down. McMurphy can't believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (politely) I count only two, including you, Mister McMurphy. Certainly not enough to change ward policy. McMurphy's hand goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Now was there anything else you wanted to discuss, Mister McMurphy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. McMurphy starts tearing his sheet of paper up into a thou pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking her watch) Then I suggest we turn our attention back to Mister Harding's problem. Would anybody care to begin? She looks around. McMurphy is slouched in his chair. Harding puts his hands up. No one else does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mister Harding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, Miss Ratched. Since our last meeting I have been reflecting, quite seriously, on the nature of my problem. Naturally, I'm referring to the capacity to obtain the necessary results in order to obtain... No, no. To personify the very existence of that relationship regardless of the function... (he stops, chews his lip, then continues) Regardless of the function, we will confront the question of... Yes. Yes. The question of... Existence... Relationship... Function... Confront... Yes, confronting us in the moment of deepest crisis... Yes, the crisis of our souls. Of our souls, which I am trying to fully understand the problem... the problem. Not to shut ourselves off, but somehow... Somehow to understand fully our capacity... to obtain... to personify... the question... existence depends... depends on the question... to reflect... to reflect... Harding, breaks off, sweating; he begins to knead his forehead and chew his nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To reflect...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence as the CAMERA REFLECTS: the room, the patients, t staff, the hallways, the hospital, the grounds, the trees the sky, ending on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it a minute. What's a man need to buy thum hotels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bromden is pressed against the wall, watching McMurphy, Martini, Scanlon and Cheswick play a game of monopoly. Th others are playing cards or just hanging around, a little chagrined. Billy is most disturbed by this separation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need four houses on every lot of the same color, Martini. Now let's go, for Christsakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it a minute. There's a flurry of money from Martini, red, green and ye bills blowing in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go, for Christsakes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your dirty roll, Cheswick. Cheswick rolls the dice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snake eyes! Hoooeee, that puts you on my Marvin Gardens, which means you owe me three hundred and fifty dollars. Cheswick starts counting out the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's thum other things? Hold it a minute. What's thum other things all over the board?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Martini) How can a man concentrate with you sitting there hallucinating a mile a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just come on with that three fifty and Martini will take care of himself... Your dice, Scanlon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme those dice. I'll blow this board to pieces. Here we go...  (throws the dice) Lebenty leben, count me over eleven, Martini... Martini picks up a house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that one, you crazy bastard, that's my house... Scanlon grabs Martini's hand and tries to get his piece b Martini won't let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break it up, God dammit! Ain't I got enough troubles without you guys messin' around... can't depend on nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the next table) Some of us ha-ha-have b-b-been here a long t-t-time, Randle, and will b b-be here long after this Wo-Wo World Series of yours is oh-oh-oh, what's the use anyway... McMurphy slams his fist down on the table, sending the monopoly pieces flying. Martini is crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use! Hooee! It'd do you birds some good just to get a little exercise lifting your arms to vote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A baseball game isn't worth the risk, my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is to me! An' if I hafta bust way outta this place to see it, I will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, how much you wanna bet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That me an' my buddy, Cheswick, we'll be downtown tomorrow watchin' the ballgame while you suckers are sittin' around this goddamn nursery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how do you propose to accomplish that little feat, my friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's between me an' myself. So why don't you boys just shove off. I got some planning to do. McMurphy sits and resumes his game of solitaire. Martini Scanlon are putting the monopoly game back together again Bromden spots (or he thinks he spots) one of the attendan listening at the door. He wants to warn the others, but doesn't know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he'll just show Miss Ratched his big thing an' she'll open the door for him. Sefelt and Frederickson smile at each other. Bromden slides along the wall toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll just use that thick skull of yours as a batterin' ram, Sefelt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, my head would just squash like an eggplant, McMurphy. Fredrickson and Sefelt snicker in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think it's funny, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you don't know how to get outta this place! Bromden reaches the door and looks out. No one is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your money where your mouth is, Taber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, you're a fucking phony, McMurphy! Bromden turns back to the room to see McMurphy slam his f down on the table; the monopoly game goes flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising and turning on the others, who back off) You want me to show ya! You want me to show ya how!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, show me. Show me how!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! He looks wildly around the room, spots the machine, cross to it and smacks it with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this thing! I'm gonna put this thing right through the window, that's how!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you're going to try to pick that thing up and shove it through the window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fuckin' A-right, I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your own two hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me the first time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet a buck you don't do it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-M-Mack, y-y-y-you c-c-can't l-l lift that thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand aside, son. Any more takers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nickel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Who else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knows he's taking a bad bet) Okay, Harding, you're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Okay, stand aside, you guys! You're usin' up my oxygen! The Acutes stand aside and McMurphy steps up to the machi He shifts his feet to get a good stance, wipes his hands his thighs, leans down and gets hold of the levers on eac side, and strains. Bromden watches, in awe of McMurphy. McMurphy turns loose, straightens up and shifts his feet a better position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Giving up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just warmin' up. He grabs the levers again. His whole body shakes with the strain. For just a second we HEAR the cement GRIND. Then breath explodes and he falls back limp against the wall. There's blood on his hands. No sound but his rasping brea He opens his eyes and looks around. Then pulls out a pocketful of IOU's and tries to sort them out, but his ha are frozen into red claws. He throws the whole bundle on floor and walks out. At the door, he turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I tried. Goddammit, I sure as hell did that much. Didn't I? McMurphy exits.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF BROMDEN
dialogues.text: looking at the machine. A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The patients are getting ready for bed when Billy approac McMurpby, who is in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-M-Mack... McMurphy turns away from Billy, who crosses to the other of the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M-M-Mack, I-I-I'm sorry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave him alone, he's pouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-Y-Y-You leave him alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, kid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Th-th-then y-y-you're n-n-not m-m mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, kid, it was my own stupidity, that's what pissed me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O-o-o-oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we're gonna have to do is pull this ballclub together for our next play. 'Kay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'K-k-kay, Mack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington, Warren and Miller are at the end of the hallw listening to a small RADIO. We can HEAR the SPORTS ANNOUN giving the line-up for the opening game of the World Seri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way down the hall, the Group Meeting is SEEN in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Group Meeting is in progress and Big Nurse is honed in Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try, Billy, try... Billy tries, but can't talk. The other Acutes are bored, restive, waiting. McMurphy has ants in his pants as Big Nurse speaks to Bil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it your idea to visit her on Sunday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y-y-y-yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I-I-I-I c-c-c-came over S-S-S Sunday m-m-m-morning after ch-ch-ch church and br-br-brought her s-s some flowers, and I s-s-said, I said, 'C-C-C-Celia, will you muh muh-muh-muh-muh...' till the girl broke out l-l-laughing. Billy laughs at himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it about her that disturbed you so, Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rubbing scars on his wrist) I was in luh-love with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy, were you afraid of her, or of her love? No response from Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the first time you attempted to commit suicide, wasn't it? (no response) You must try to talk about it, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, the man doesn't want to talk, so get off his back an' let's get on to some new business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister McMurphy, the purpose of this meeting is therapy. Group therapy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, the hell with that crap! The World Series is goin' on right' now an' that's therapy also!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me pose a question to the group: do any of you feel that Mister McMurphy is perhaps imposing his personal desires on you too much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does that have to do with it? This is an important event and I want a vote on it!
